Project Description  The  Project  addresses  both  supply-side  and  demand-side 
constraints within the agriculture sector. It is designed to promote 
agricultural commercialization2 through extension and training and 
to support the growth of value-added enterprises by improving 
access  to  information  and  markets  and  creating  an  enabling 
environment for investments in agribusinesses. The Project will 
address  key  constraints  regarding  productivity  and 
competitiveness  of  the  agriculture  sector  that  impact  on  the 
income of small farmers and economic growth of the Lao PDR, 
including providing for strategic road linkages to the East-West 
and  North-South  corridors,  where  commerce  and  trade  are 
beginning to develop. The Project will help to improve the living 
standards  of  rural  populations  in  selected  districts  of 
Savannakhet,  Champassak,  Khammouan,  and  Vientiane  by 
reinforcing  recent  gains  from  increased  rice  production  and 
promoting  commercial  agricultural  growth.  In  line  with  the 
decentralization strategy of the Government, provincial and district 
administrations will be used in implementation of the Project.  
   
Rationale   Agriculture is the Lao PDR's dominant sector, accounting for half 
of gross domestic product and more than 85% of employment. 
Over 85% of people in the country live in rural areas, making a 
living largely by subsistence cultivation of rice. Fifty-three percent 
of the rural population live in poverty. The incidence of poverty, 
which  is  closely  linked  to  agricultural  performance,  can  be 
reduced by moving farmers beyond subsistence farming to more 
diversified and commercial agricultural production of a number of 
cash  crops  with  ready  markets  in  neighboring  countries.  The 
irrigated floodplain of the Mekong produces most of the country’s 
marketable  surplus  of  rice  and  other  crops  and  offers  the 
strongest potential at present for commercialization of agriculture. 
However, even in these areas, rice productivity is below that of its 
neighbors,  and  the  productivity  and  quality  of  nonrice  crops 
remain  low  because  of  limited  information  on  markets,  low 
technical expertise, restricted access to markets for inputs and 
products,  unavailability  of  credit,  low  domestic  demand,  and a

Objectives and Scope  The purpose of the Project is to promote commercial smallholder 
agriculture  and  associated  agribusiness,  with  the  overall 
objectives of achieving sustained increases in rural incomes and 
long-term reductions in rural poverty. Specific objectives are to (i) 
achieve increased production and marketing of diversified, nonrice 
dry-season  cash  crops,  livestock,  and  fisheries;  (ii)  improve 
smallholder  access  to  domestic  and  international  markets  and 
market information; and (iii) increase investment in value-adding 
agribusiness.  
 
To achieve these objectives, the Project has four components: 
(i) farmer  support  services  to  improve  farmers’  technical 
knowledge of integrated farming systems, and access to market 
information  and  inputs;  (ii)  agribusiness  and  marketing  to 
stimulate investment in agribusinesses; (iii) rural infrastructure to 
improve  physical  access  to  produce  markets  and  reduce 
marketing costs; and (iv) project management.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) for the Smallholder Development Project. 
The report also describes technical assistance (TA) for Agribusiness Support and Training, and 
if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the 
Board, will approve this TA grant. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  The Government’s development goal is to reduce poverty by half by 2005 and for the 
Lao PDR to graduate from the status of least developed country by 2020. The Government 
targets broad-based economic growth of 6–7% per annum over the next 5 years. The strategic 
approach  is  to  reduce  poverty  through  human  and  rural  development,  and  people’s 
participation, focusing on (i) agriculture and forestry, (ii) education, (iii) health, and (iv) road 
infrastructure. To achieve its ambitious objectives with limited financial and human resources, 
the  Government  will  need  to  accelerate  economic  development  through  private  sector  or 
private-public  initiatives,  which  will  in  turn  contribute  significantly  to  its  poverty  reduction 
program.  Following  the  admission  of  the  Lao  PDR  to  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian 
Nations (ASEAN), considerable potential to exploit export markets has been created. This would 
improve with the scheduled 2005 implementation of the ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA) and 
entry into the World Trade Organization. As well, the development of the East-West Corridor of 
the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS)—comprising the central provinces of central Myanmar, 
northeastern and northwestern Thailand, lower Lao PDR, and central Viet Nam—represents an 
area of very high potential for the development of agroindustries, from which the Lao PDR can 
potentially benefit.  
 
  1.  Agriculture  
 
3.  Agriculture is the Lao PDR's dominant sector, accounting for half of gross domestic 
product and more than 85% of employment. About 95% of the rural population is dependent on 
agricultural production, mainly rice, for a living. The majority of Lao farmers practice subsistence 
agriculture, and poverty is widespread. While the national poverty rate is 39%, the rate in rural 
areas is 44%, with the rural poor making up 87% of the total poor.3 Rice is cultivated by over 
80%  of  the  population,  mainly  for  their  own  food  use.  Rice  yields  are  still  low  by  Asian 
standards; national average yields are within the relatively low range of 1.5–3.0 tons per hectare 
(ha) compared with 6–7 tons/ha in other countries. See Appendix 1 for the sector analysis. 
 
4.  The irrigated areas on the floodplains of the Mekong and its tributaries produce most of 
the country’s marketable surplus of rice and other crops. About one fourth of households in this 
region grow maize, and about a third grow some vegetable crops, either in irrigated fields, 
kitchen  gardens,  or  along  riverbanks.  Commonly  grown  vegetables  include  chili,  cabbage, 
cucumber, eggplant, and onion. Other nonrice crops include sugar cane, peanut, tobacco, 
sesame, and fruit trees (most notably mango and tamarind). Although most households depend

5.  While,  in  1990,  rice  production  was  1.3  million  tons,  with  the  help  of  considerable

competitive advantage lies in nonrice niche markets. However, nonrice crop production and 
quality remain low even in the most highly productive agricultural areas. 
 
2.  Agricultural Extension and Marketing 
 
6.  Since the revolution in 1975, public sector extension in the Lao PDR has been vertically 
structured from the central to the district levels. At the top, the Ministry of Agriculture and 
Forestry (MAF) is organized by line departments (e.g., irrigation, forestry, crops, and livestock). 
In each of the 18 provinces and 139 districts, the central structure is mirrored in the provincial 
agriculture  and  forestry  services  (PAFSs)  and  the  district  agriculture  and  forestry  offices 
(DAFOs), respectively. This structure has been in place for some 26 years. Although the PAFSs 
and  DAFOs  employ  collectively  some  6,000  persons,  lack  of  staff  capacity  and  operating 
budgets have severely constrained their functions, rendering them dysfunctional. The main 
functions of DAFOs, in the past, have been to collect production data, regulate activities related 
to  land  and  forest  allocations  and  issue  permits,  and  organize  village  labor  for  basic 
infrastructure construction. Very limited technical assistance to farmers has been provided, and 
very little has been aimed at assisting farmers improve their productivity. 
 
7.  However, since the mid-1990s, several initiatives by aid agencies have demonstrated 
viable models for strengthening extension in the Lao PDR. With assistance under ADB TA 
1745-LAO and TA 2333-LAO (Institutional Development and Strengthening of the Ministry of 
Agriculture and Forestry) in 1993, and several donors, a national strategy for extension through 
farming systems extension workers (FSEW) was developed. This concept was pilot tested in 
four districts between 1994 and 1997 under the Pilot Extension Project (PEP), financed by the 
Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) through the Novartis Foundation. The 
concept of FSEW departed from the traditional assignment of staff at the district level to focus 
on a generalist farming systems approach in assigned groups of villages. The approach to 
extension  built  around  the  National  Agricultural  and  Forestry  Extension  Service  (NAFES) 
underpinning  the  human  resource  development  component  of  the  Government’s  Strategic 
Vision  for  the  Agricultural  Sector  was  presented  to  the  international  aid  community  in 
November 1999. 
 
8.  The Lao marketing chain for agricultural produce is underdeveloped, with significant 
gaps in critical areas such as inadequacy of primary markets, inadequate business support, and 
absence  of  business  commodity  traders  except  for  rice  and  livestock.  There  are  also 
constrained and inadequate mechanisms for efficient cross-border trading. Despite the setting 
up of AFTA to facilitate the free movement of goods and services, compliance with AFTA is 
inadequate or non-existent in many areas.

  3.  Rural Financial Institutions 
 
9.  The Lao financial sector currently comprises the specialized state-owned Agricultural 
Promotion Bank (APB), three state-owned commercial banks (SOCBs),4 three joint venture 
banks  (JVBs),5  and  eight  foreign  commercial  banks  (FCBs).6  APB  is  the  only  significant 
institutional source of rural finance at present. APB reaches rural households mainly through 
credit groups and has reportedly established 20,000 such groups with an average membership 
of seven families per group. APB operates three branches in Louang Phrabang, Savannakhet, 
and Champassak; 47 service units in rural areas; and six subservice units in Vientiane Province. 
The SOCBs have branches in several provinces, while the JVBs and FCBs have no branches 
and hence no provincial outreach other than in the area around Vientiane Municipality. 
 
10.  As of 31 December 2001, outstanding loans for agriculture in all banks totaled the 
equivalent of about $30 million, of which $9 million was outstanding from the SOCBs, about $20 
million from APB, and the rest from the JVBs and FCBs. APB is the premier agricultural finance 
institution, whose portfolio is predominantly in agriculture and agribusiness. At the end of 2001, 
APB had total assets of $29 million equivalent (KN277 billion), of which cash and deposits 
comprised $3.9 million (KN37 billion), outstanding loans $20 million (KN190 billion), and fixed 
and other assets totaled $5.3 million (KN50 billion). Outstanding loans comprised about $11.6 
million (KN110 billion) in short-term lending for production and $8.4 million (KN80 billion) in 
medium-  and  long-term  loans.  APB’s  liabilities  comprised  $11.6  million  (KN91  billion)  in 
demand, savings, and short-term fixed deposits, $1 million (KN10 billion) in 2-year certificates of 
deposit (which is earmarked for policy lending), about $4.9 million (KN47 billion) in multilateral 
development institution credit lines,7 $6.3 million or 20% (KN60 billion) in capital, and $5.2 
million (KN50 billion) in other liabilities. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Problem Analysis8 
11.  Agriculture Sector Issues. Rice is the dominant crop, occupying 68% of the total 
cultivated  area  (of  1.8  million  ha,  according  to  satellite  imagery).  Other  annual  crops  and 
permanent crops account for only 9% and 8%, respectively, highlighting the predominant role of 
rice and of subsistence farming in the Lao PDR agricultural economy. Agricultural productivity is 
low due to inefficient practices, low input use, and low farm mechanization. This is primarily due 
to the predominance of subsistence-oriented rice production whereby farmers adopt low input 
methods to meet subsistence needs at minimal cost. Only 28% of households used chemical 
fertilizers in 1999, and less than one third of households use any form of mechanization. Low 
technical expertise; limited access to domestic and international markets for inputs and outputs; 
lack of access to market information; constraints to export, inter-provincial, and external trade; 
low domestic demand; and the dearth of local agribusinesses are some of the main reasons 
why  agricultural  production  has  been  inefficient.  Limited  human  resource  capacity,  poor

12.  To stimulate growth in agriculture and to raise rural incomes, it is necessary to move 
beyond subsistence farming to more diversified, commercial agricultural production by assisting 
subsistence and semicommercial farmers to transit from their present low input systems to more 
productive,  higher  input,  and  profitable  commercial  farming  systems.  To  facilitate  the

in commercial agricultural development to link producers, wholesalers, and retail buyers is 
needed. Major factors contributing to low agricultural production and diversification include 
(i) limited access to financial services, (ii) underdeveloped and weak research and extension, 
(iii) underdeveloped seed production system and lack of improved seed and planting material, 
(iv) lack of knowledge of improved technology and lack of skill of MAF staff, (v) limited market 
outlets and poor post harvest facilities, and (vi) high cost of transportation and lack of all-
weather roads. The underdeveloped research and lack of improved seed and planting material, 
while not being binding constraints, since these are now readily available from neighboring 
countries, need to be further studied for future strengthening.  
 
13.  About half of all households keep buffaloes for draught power, and a third have cattle 
(the average number of cattle per household is higher than that for buffalo, though). Pig raising 
is also common. However, only a third of households currently vaccinate their cattle. The 
livestock trade with Thailand is significant, but poor cattle and livestock health hamper this trade 
and  expose  farmers  to  the  opportunistic  and  rent-seeking  behavior  of  middlemen  and 
unscrupulous officials. Fish is a major source of protein, accounting for 40% of total protein 
intake. Fish farming is characterized as extensive low density without feeding to semi-extensive 
farming  with  a  small  amount  of  feeding.  Despite  the  Government’s  support  through  the 
operation of fish stations with hatcheries, mortality rates have been high. The main constraints 
are lack of technical capacity within MAF and lack of a consistent technology for fish breeding.  
 
14.  Potential agribusiness investors perceive the Lao PDR to be a high-risk country in which 
to conduct business. High costs for registrations, hidden administrative costs, and the weak 
legal  framework  impose  extra  burdens  in  this  regard.  Nontariff  barriers  and  other  border 
irregularities, and the slow response of Lao farmers to demand compound the constraints to 
agribusiness viability. Partly because of the large component of subsistence agriculture, the 
marketing system has remained underdeveloped. Interregional distribution is limited to some 
fruits and fish. Regional market prices vary significantly and reflect the poor market information, 
poor quality of produce, poor transport facilities, and licensing requirements.  
 
15.  Agricultural  Extension  and  Marketing.  Extension  budgets  are  limited,  and  the  main 
function of the DAFO has, therefore, been confined to collecting data on production, carrying out 
regulatory  functions,  and  occasionally  mobilizing  villagers  to  construct  basic  infrastructure. 
While some assistance to farmers has been provided, such as livestock vaccination, not much 
has  been  done  to  help  farmers  improve  their  productivity.  However,  there  is  a  growing 
awareness of the importance of extension and the role of MAF in promoting agricultural growth, 
which has resulted in the decentralization of the extension system and assistance by bilateral 
and multilateral agencies, such as under the Sustainable Irrigated Agriculture Project, Farmer 
Integrated Agriculture Training Project, Integrated Pest Management Project, PEP, and ADB TA

5 
2333-LAO to strengthen MAF. (See Appendix 3 for external assistance.) Recognizing this, the 
Government has tried hard to provide more funds for extension activities. External support is 
needed to operationalize this vision. 
 
16.  Studies show that the weakest link in the marketing chain on the demand side of Lao 
agriculture is the shortage and/or absence of primary markets in many areas.  Primary markets 
are the point of first sale from producers to local consumers and to wholesalers, and the 
absence of such basic facilities deters farmers from producing for the market and improving 
their livelihood. On the supply side, local supply of agricultural inputs is constrained by the 
absence of primary markets. Shortage of inputs is a major constraint to increasing commercial 
agricultural production. 
 
17.  Accessibility and Availability of Financial Services. Because rural incomes fluctuate 
and a multitude of risks affect income and consumption, rural households need access to 
financial services to help stabilize income and consumption and alleviate chronic and transitory 
food insecurity. Chronic food insecurity can be alleviated by increasing production through the 
provision  of  credit,  while  transitory  food  security,  which  involves  income  and  consumption 
smoothing, requires savings and insurance facilities. 
 
18.  Accessibility of rural financial services is important to ensure that farmers and rural 
businesses have the wherewithal to adopt new technologies and practices that can improve 
their income. In 2000, ADB approved a cluster TA for Rural Finance Development to help 
develop  a  sustainable  market-oriented  rural  finance  system  and  to  strengthen  APB.  The 
International  Monetary  Fund,  World  Bank,  and  ADB  are  also  currently  collaborating  to 
strengthen the financial sector (under the World Bank Financial Management Adjustment Credit 
and  the  ADB  Banking  Sector  Reform  Program  Loan),  and  the  Government  is  pledging 
significant reforms in the enabling environment and banking sector. Under these initiatives, 
credit lines to APB have been strongly discouraged until these reforms and those relating to 
governance,  audit,  disclosure  and  accounting  practices,  risk  management,  and  human 
resources development (supported under ADB TA 3413-LAO) in APB specifically are carried 
out.  
 
19.  There are currently no regulations for microfinance institutions. There is no specific 
credit union law. The legal basis for chartering credit unions (or credit cooperatives) is the 
Regulations  on  Credit  Cooperatives,  No.  02/SB,  dated  15  November  1994  issued  by  the 
governor of the Bank of Lao PDR (BOL).9 BOL regulations address some areas of credit union 
registration; powers; governance; prudential standards; supervision; and the general powers of 
savings and credit unions to acquire, hold, and dispose of assets, to enter into contracts, to offer 
deposit and loan services, to determine their own interest rates, and to borrow and to invest in 
authorized  investments.  However,  there  are  several  provisions  still  lacking,  notably  those 
related to investment, membership, loan write-off, external audit, external borrowing, and loan 
portfolio concentration. So far, only the Coopératives de Crédits pour le Soutien aux Petites 
Unités de Production, comprising nine partner cooperatives, have successfully formed under 
this legislation and operated in rural areas, but on a very small scale, reaching only 900 
members and with a loan outstanding of about $140,000 (financed by Société d'Investissement 
et de Développement International and the Association pour le Soutien et le Développement 
des Sociétés Paysannes au Laos). The Phongsali Decentralized Credit Network in Phongsali

20.  Policy Constraints. Other weaknesses that plague the financial and business sectors 
relate to the legal environment. While a framework of legislation for the operation of commercial 
businesses  has  been  developed,  there  is  much  uncertainty  regarding  it.  Among  the 
uncertainties are constraints caused by a lack of dissemination of legislation, limits on judicial 
capacity, incomplete repeal of legislation that is technically no longer in force, overlap between 
laws and between decrees, uncertainty of title registration procedures, incomplete land titling 
and  associated  high  transaction  costs,  and  time-consuming  legal  processes  in  relation  to 
contract enforcement and debt recovery. These constraints seriously hinder sound lending by 
banks and discourage foreign investors and foreign banks. 
 
2.  Opportunities 
21.  With its small population and abundant (but largely untapped) natural resources, the Lao 
PDR is in a strong position to produce goods for export to neighboring markets, which have 
large populations with relatively high incomes but suffer land and other resource pressures and 
increasing urbanization. Just outside the Lao PDR border live at least 200 million people. As 
industrial development accelerates in these countries, agricultural land resources are shifting to 
the non-agricultural sectors, and these populations could become major consumers of rice, 
livestock, vegetables, and other farm produce from the Lao PDR. 
 
22.  Despite  the  constraints  currently  faced  by  Lao  agriculture,  some  Lao  agricultural 
commodities are exported through unofficial border trade mechanisms to the People’s Republic 
of China, Thailand, and Viet Nam. These include maize, soybean, groundnut, cotton, tobacco, 
sesame, red bean, cabbage, banana, tamarind, watermelon, mulberry bark and other nontimber 
forest products, buffalo, cattle, and pigs.10 The fact that such trade with neighboring countries 
takes place suggests that a demand  for some Lao agricultural products exists. Crops identified 
as  having  potential  for  export  and/or  import  substitution  based  on  comparative  advantage 
analysis are maize, peanut, soybean, sesame, sunflower, sorghum, and safflower for field 
crops; grape, mandarin, sapodilla, orange, durian, rambutan, cashew, longan, and tamarind for 
fruits; and coffee, sugar cane, cotton, and sericulture among industrial crops. By ensuring that 
AFTA rules are enforced, Lao agricultural produce should be able to enter Thailand and Viet 
Nam freely, thereby benefiting farmers from better prices and the country from more trade. 
 
23.  Livestock, an integral part of most family farm systems, contributes to almost half the 
average income of farmers. The Lao PDR has a comparative advantage among the neighboring 
export markets, and there is considerable potential to increase livestock production and value 
added products for export. Major constraints to the expansion of livestock production are lack of 
an integrated program of animal health, nutrition, and breeding; and lack of support services in 
marketing and market information systems. By improvements in livestock health and mortality 
farmers can ensure better farm household income. Similarly, Lao PDR can achieve comparative 
advantage in fish farming, vis-à-vis its neighbors, by applying the appropriate technology in 
breeding and rearing of fish. 
 
24.  The  Government  recognizes  that  growth  in  the  Lao  agriculture  sector  has  been 
constrained by (i) the limited capacity of public sector institutions and human resources; (ii) an

communications infrastructure; (iv) unavailability of rural finance and undeveloped input and

committed to a market-based economy with equitable distribution of the benefits of growth. In

on improvements in farmer knowledge, awareness, and capacity to increase agricultural output 
and create marketable surpluses to meet growing domestic and regional demand in both local 
and  external  raw  commodity  and  agribusiness  processing  markets.  In  recognition  of  the 
importance of agricultural extension services, the Government recently increased MAF’s budget 
by 50%. 
 
25.  It is generally recognized that credit in the presence of technology, extension, and 
markets can speed up development. In the project areas, farmers and other rural inhabitants 
face difficulty in accessing financial services. This problem is compounded by the restructuring 
of APB and by reforms in the financial sector under ADB’s cluster TA and the Banking Sector 
Reform  Program  Loan.  Simple  revision  in  collateral  regulations,  group-based  lending,  and 
providing  loans  of  appropriate  duration  could  increase  the  coverage  of  farmers  under  the 
Project. By introducing more loan products and innovative financial services, APB could reach 
out  to  traders  and  merchants  supplying  inputs  and  small-scale  machinery  to  farmers. 
Merchants, in turn, could extend credit facilities to project beneficiaries on normal trade credit 
terms. The Law on Cooperatives provides the framework for the creation of credit cooperatives 
involving the private sector, which could serve the rural population and promote increased 
competition for formal financial institutions. Under the ADB cluster TA, it is proposed to form 
credit unions under the auspices of APB, after the completion of the ongoing diagnostic study of 
APB.

3.  Rural Infrastructure 
36.  The Project will provide for the rehabilitation of 89.5 kilometers (km) and construction of 
70.8 km of strategic roads, identified as the highest priority rural access roads in the project 
area. These roads will lower transport costs and facilitate the flow of agricultural technology, 
inputs, and produce among production centers, primary markets, and strategic GMS markets. 
The selected roads link existing west-east and north-south marketing corridors (primarily to 
Thailand and Viet Nam, and to the People’s Republic of China) to agricultural areas that have 
the potential to adopt agriculture and livestock productivity-enhancing technology.23 
 
37.  These roads are (i) the Pakse-Champassak-Soukhouma-Mounlapamok road (Road 14-
A), which links the impoverished, but potentially productive, lower Mekong plain of Champassak 
Province to the highly commercial east-west corridor of Pakxong-Pakse and the Thai border; 
(ii) the Champhone-Xonbuli road in Savannakhet Province, which links the potentially productive 
Xonbuli District to the commercially active east-west corridor in Savannakhet that connects to 
the border region with Thailand; and (iii) the Songkhone-Thapasoun road, which links the 
commercial center of Songkhone District in Savannakhet Province to a key Mekong River 
border trading market with Thailand. The selected roads are within the commercially viable 
zones of the three selected agricultural plains, which serve large populations who need access 
to marketing corridors.

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
60.  The project components focus on activities in which the Lao PDR has an underlying 
comparative advantage and which offer smallholder farmers opportunities for increased food 
security and greater incomes. The Project has an estimated base case economic internal rate of 
return (EIRR) of 19.9%. The bulk of project benefits will come from increments of rice, dry 
season field and vegetable crops, and reductions in vehicle operating costs (the latter comprise 
about one fifth of the total project benefits). Nonquantified/valued benefits include those from 
livestock and fisheries demonstrations, greater levels of smallholder technical and business 
skills, greater levels of agribusiness activities and improved social cohesion. The Project is 
relatively robust (if costs go up 20% the EIRR is 17.0%) and risk-free—the probability of the 
actual EIRR being less than the opportunity cost of capital is low. The estimated financial 
internal rate of return is some 17.8%. This is lower than the EIRR, as some crop prices remain 
de  facto  affected  by  government  purchasing  policies;  despite  this,  the  proposed  project 
interventions are financially viable and sufficiently attractive at the farm level to encourage 
smallholder  participation  (see  Appendix  13).  The  main  risk  to  the  farmer  support  services 
component is lack of accessibility to financial services from APB. 
 
61.  Implementation of the farmer support services and rural infrastructure components faces 
minimal external risks. The technologies chosen for implementation have been tested and 
proven before in the Lao PDR, and it is expected that substantial benefits will accrue with the 
implementation of these two components. The farmer support services component, however, 
runs  certain  risks  relating  to  accessibility  of  financial  services.  Rural  finance  is  still  in  an 
embryonic stage in the Lao PDR, and is not yet fully understood and supported in a manner that

18 
enables rural financial institutions to operate in a sustainable manner. The ADB TA on Rural 
Finance Development and the proposed Banking Sector Reform Program are expected to 
improve the enabling environment and support the creation of credit cooperatives. 
 
62.  The  bigger  risk  to  the  Project  is  to  the  agribusiness  and  marketing  development 
component. The Lao PDR is still seen as a risky place to invest. The success of this component 
therefore  depends  on  improvements  in  the  enabling  environment  for  agribusiness.  This 
includes, especially, proper implementation at the local level of national policies prohibiting price 
ceilings, monopoly protection, and internal trade restrictions, as well as reductions in extralegal 
rent seeking by local officials. Implementation of a supportive enabling environment will be the 
subject of specific assurances and ongoing loan covenants, and will be monitored in terms of its 
impact on businesses and entrepreneurs receiving business support services from the Project. 
The success of this component also depends on the supply of credit increasing due to reforms 
promoted through other projects in the financial sector (e.g., the ADB-financed Rural Finance 
TA and Banking Sector Reform Program Loan). While these risks are real, they will be mitigated 
by TA to identify creditworthy businesses and assisting those businesses to put together good 
business plans and credit applications. They will also be addressed through training of local 
officials and promotion of policy dialogue between officials and agribusinesses. Moreover, the 
Banking Sector Reform Program Loan will support needed reforms in the area of contract 
enforcement that will also improve the investment environment. 
 
63.  The Project is expected to reduce food insecurity and increase incomes of households 
living below the poverty line, which constitute approximately 22% of total households in the 
project area, through provision of appropriate technology, improved livestock production and 
maintenance practices, and participatory training and extension. Female-headed households, 
which constitute 14% of total households in the project area, are expected to benefit from 
improved access to new technologies, group-based activities including financial training and 
services, improved market access, and opportunities for self employment. 
 
64.  Resettlements  impacts  will  be  addressed  through  the  Involuntary  Resettlement 
Framework (Appendix 6) detailing the types of expected impacts and the entitlements matrix for 
different  types  of  affected  persons/households,  as  well  as  a  sample  Resettlement  Plan

A.  Performance Indicators 
 
1.  Agriculture employs 85% of the national labor force in the Lao People’s Democratic 
Republic (Lao PDR) and is the largest contributor to the national gross domestic product (GDP) 
(at around 53% of the total in 2001). In 2001, rice contributed 68.4% to the agricultural GDP, 
while livestock contributed 27.7% and nonrice crops 3.9%. Industry and services have been 
contributing an increasing amount to the national GDP in recent years (their contribution was 
approximately 22% and 25%, respectively in 2001). Although agriculture remains the dominant 
sector  of  the  national  economy,  investments  in  the  sector  from  all  sources  (external  and 
Government) have averaged less than 19% of the national budget. Agricultural growth was 
about 4% in 2001, less robust than in previous years. With primary production being largely for 
subsistence and not being well integrated into a subregional or regional economy, agriculture 
has been partly insulated from the effects of the regional financial crisis. 
 
2.  The majority of farmers practice subsistence agriculture, and poverty is widespread. 
While the national poverty rate is 39%, the rate in rural areas is 43.8%, and the rural poor make 
up 87% of the country’s poor.1 Agricultural productivity remains low at about $199/worker-year. 
This is compared with $331/worker-year in Viet Nam and $347/worker-year in Thailand.2 The 
average household income from farming is about $200/hectare (ha). This is compared with 
$357/ha in Thailand and $320/ha in Viet Nam. 
 
3.  Rice is the anchor of the farming system. Rice accounts for over 90% of total crop 
production. Nearly 95% of farming households grow rice for their own use. Glutinous rice 
accounts for over 90% of total planted area. Rice yields are low by Asian standards. Figures 
vary by source and across different parts of the country, according to whether irrigation is 
available or not, and between upland and lowland areas, but overall national average yields are 
within the relatively low range of 1.5 to 2.5 tons/ha/crop.3 However, for the wide majority of 
rainfed (i.e., non-irrigated) rice farmers, yields are closer to 2 tons/ha and below.4  Because of 
high  postharvest  and  milling  losses  (55–60%),  Lao  PDR  needs  to  produce  400  kg  of 
paddy/capita to obtain the 180 kg/capita of milled rice consumed. With a population of 5 million 
people, it needs to produce 2 million tons annually for rice self-sufficiency. The country has 
experienced rice deficits consistently until 1998, when it began to achieve a small surplus.5 
Production needs to increase by 50,000 tons annually to keep pace with the population growth 
rate of 2.6% per year.

C.  Agricultural Marketing and Demand Side Constraints 
 
7.  In general, agricultural marketing suffers from a lack of physical access to produce 
markets related to poor infrastructure.  Primary market infrastructure is informal and lacks basic 
amenities (access, communications, covered areas, cement floors, secure stall spaces). There 
are significant gaps in the marketing chain from producers to retailers. The marketing chain 
suffers from inadequate competition and is constrained by poor physical access and limited 
produce supplies. For example, there is an acute shortage of primary market facilities for 
farmers to trade their produce to retailers and wholesalers. This constraint both causes a 
shortage of wholesalers and traders for agricultural produce (particularly nonrice) and creates 
inefficiency in the marketing system.  
 
8.  The marketing of agricultural products in Lao PDR tends to be regionally confined, 
resulting  in  significant  variation  in  market  prices  from  region  to  region.    Such  regionally 
unbalanced  markets  are  created  by  (i)  formal  and  informal  regulations  that  prevent  free 
movement of goods, (ii) prohibitive fees and administrative costs, (iii) poor access roads and an 
underdeveloped farm-to-market road network, (iv) transportation shortages and high transport 
costs, (v) small urban demand, and (vi) interregional transport fees and controls in Lao PDR. 
 
9.  There are several channels for marketing of agricultural produce.  The State Enterprises 
for Food and Crop Promotion (SEFCP), import-export companies, commercial associations, and 
processing  factories  buy  rice,  meat,  and  other  food  commodities  from  local  markets  or 
middlemen.  For  purchase  of  rice,  middlemen  usually  visit  and  buy  directly  from  individual 
households during the harvesting period. For nonrice produce, farmers usually must do their 
own marketing. There are 448 wholesale and retail produce markets in the Lao PDR. Of these, 
13 are privately owned and managed, 101 are Government-leased and privately managed, 73 
are managed by provincial and district administrations and the remaining 261 are village and 
community  managed.14  No  markets  handling  fresh  food  have  cooling  facilities  or  display 
cabinets. Fresh foods are displayed on tables with little regard for sanitation or quality grading. 
In  general,  market  areas  are  small  and  limited,  and  buyers  accept  ungraded  and 
undifferentiated produce.

commanding share of the market for paddy (70%), with the remaining 30% share in the hands

13.  Potential international agribusiness investors perceive the Lao PDR to be a high-risk

D.  Strategic Opportunities and Challenges  
 
15.  Immediately adjacent to the Lao PDR borders live at least 200 million Thais, Chinese, 
and Vietnamese. As industrial development accelerates in these three countries, paddy and 
agricultural land resources are shifting to the non-agriculture sectors. There is a corresponding 
decline  in  domestic  food  production  amid  their  growing  populations.  As  a  result,  these 
populations could become significant consumers of rice, livestock, vegetables, and other farm 
produce from the Lao PDR and other neighboring countries. 
 
16.  Since its move towards a market economy, a number of private investors (both local and 
foreign) have established agroprocessing units within the country. This has created demand in 
the areas near the processing plants. With the development of urban areas, the domestic 
market for diversified agricultural output has grown. There is additional purchasing interest from 
foreign buyers, notably from Thailand, but also from the People’s Republic of China and Viet 
Nam. Coffee, peanut, soybean, mungbean, corn, livestock, fisheries, nontimber forest products, 
cotton, fruits, and vegetables are products in demand. Some farmers are already responding to 
these market opportunities 
 
17.  To stimulate growth in agriculture and raise rural incomes, there is an opportunity to 
move beyond subsistence farming to more diversified, commercial agricultural production. With 
two of it’s neighbors, Viet Nam and Thailand, being dominant low-cost rice producers in the

E.  Government Policies and Strategies 
 
18.  The Government is committed to a market-based economy with equitable distribution of 
the  benefits  of  growth.  In  November  1999,  with  ADB  assistance  under  TA  2883-LAO: 
Agriculture Strategy Study,17 the Government presented its strategic vision for the agriculture 
sector at a conference of aid agencies. The strategy focused on (i) increasing rural income by 
developing market-oriented agriculture, and changing public institutions and policies to better 
serve this aim; (ii) recognizing the preeminent role of the private sector and working to improve 
the business and investment environment; (iii) achieving a better balance in investments in the 
sector;18 (iv) addressing the respective opportunities and constraints of the country’s upland and 
lowland farming systems and communities; (v) improving environmental management of the 
county’s natural resources; and (vi) improving and sustaining investments made in supporting 
infrastructure (primarily irrigation and rural roads). The agriculture strategy study demonstrated 
that for a range of crops (including rice, maize, groundnut, cotton, sugarcane, and coffee) the 
country’s  production  is  competitive  in  the  region  and,  with  the  application  of  improved 
technology, it could be among the world’s low-cost producers of several commodities. The 
Government  has  affirmed  its  commitment  to  trade  liberalization.19  In  this  context,  the 
Government views assistance with the promotion of market-oriented, diversified agriculture (and 
its own Commodity Development Program) as key to improving smallholder livelihood and 
expanding the nation’s economy. 
 
19.  To improve rural livelihoods through increased production of higher value crops, the 
Government seeks to (i) strengthen its adaptive research and extension services; (ii) facilitate 
the development of private sector trade and agroprocessing; (iii) improve farmers’ access to 
market information and supporting infrastructure; and (iv) increase the availability of credit for 
farmers, traders, and processors. In essence, the Government views commodity production as 
being market driven, with the initiatives coming from the private sector. The Government views 
its role as a facilitator to assist and advise smallholder farmers and to encourage their linkages 
to markets, traders, and processors.

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The Smallholder Development Project in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao 
PDR) is aimed at strengthening the rural economy by promoting market-oriented, diversified 
agricultural  production  on  smallholder  farms  and  by  improving  market  links.  However, 
diversifying agricultural production involves various types of interventions with potential impacts 
on the environment. Therefore, the Project has been classified by the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) as an environment category “B” project. An initial environmental examination (IEE) and a 
summary initial environmental examination (SIEE) for the whole project as well as a sample IEE 
for a road subproject were prepared in accordance with ADB’s requirements for environmental 
assessment.  
 
2.  The objective of the IEE is to identify impacts, evaluate their severity, recommend 
mitigation measures, and propose a monitoring plan for use in project implementation. Project 
components  to  be  financed  under  the  loan  involve  institutional  adjustments,  farm  service 
extension work such as training, and various types of physical infrastructure. The IEE covers a 
wide scope of potential environmental impacts associated with these interventions. Many of 
these impacts occur on the Project in only a minor degree. For instance, the IEE provides 
guidance  related  to  rangeland  management,  because  it  is  assumed  that  with  intensified 
extension activity some additional livestock rearing will occur; however the loan project will not 
finance improved pasture for livestock grazing, which is expected to be undertaken at the 
household level. The type of impacts generally associated with large livestock operations are 
unlikely to occur.   
 
3.  The SIEE follows guidelines provided in Environmental Assessment Requirements of the 
Asian Development Bank, the Environmental Guidelines for Selected Agriculture and Natural 
Resources  Development  Projects,  and  the  Handbook  for  Incorporation  of  Integrated  Pest 
Management in Agriculture Projects. Host country guidelines taken into account include the 
Environmental  Protection  Law;  the  Environmental  Impact  Assessment  Regulations  of  the 
Science,  Technology,  and  Environment  Agency,  and  the  “Environmental  Guidelines  for 
Reducing  the  Environmental  Effects  of  Road  Projects  in  Lao  PDR”  of  the  Ministry  of 
Communication, Transport, Post, and Construction (MCTPC), which was issued officially by 
Prime Minister’s Decree No: 05/PM dated 14/1/95.  
 
B.  Description of the Project 
 
4.  The  purpose  of  the  Project  is  to  promote  commercial  smallholder  agriculture  and 
associated agribusiness, with the overall objectives of achieving sustained increases in rural 
incomes  and  long-term  reductions  in  rural  poverty.  Specific  objectives  are  to  (i)  achieve 
increased production and marketing of diversified, nonrice dry season cash crops, livestock, and 
fisheries; (ii) improve smallholder access to domestic and international markets and market 
information; and (iii) increase investment in value-adding agribusiness.  
5.  To  achieve  these  objectives,  the  Project  has  four  components:  (i)  farmer  support 
services to improve farmers’ technical knowledge of integrated farming systems, and access to 
market  information  and  inputs,  (ii)  agribusiness  and  marketing  to  stimulate  investment  in 
agribusinesses, (iii) rural infrastructure, and (iv) project management. The total cost of the 
Project over 6 years is estimated at $15.2 million equivalent, including physical and price

contingencies, interest during construction, taxes, and duties. Of the total cost, $6.5 million or 
43% is foreign exchange cost and $8.7 million equivalent or 57% is local currency.  
 
6.  The Project covers 16 districts in four provinces of the Lao PDR. These include six 
districts in Savannakhet, six in Champassak, two in Khammouane, and two in Vientiane. These 
provinces currently have the highest potential for commercial agricultural development where 
factor and product markets are beginning to function and complementary infrastructure such as 
irrigation, roads, electricity, and some agribusiness development is beginning to emerge. As 
well, they present the most interest to potential foreign investors.  
C.  Description of the Environment 
 
7.  The Project is generally centered in lowland or mid-range areas at varying elevation from 
lows of around 100 meters (m) along the Mekong River in Southern Champassak and Marketing 
Lines of Communication (MLOC) areas in Savannakhet, increasing to around 200 m in the mid-
range Bachieng District in Champassak and Xonbuli in Savannakhet, up to a high elevation of 
1,200 m for upland reaches around Pakxong situated on the Bolovens Plateau in Champassak. 
The two districts in Vientiane Province range in elevation from 180 to 210 m.  
 
8.  Climate  represents  a  significant  factor  in  agricultural  production,  determining,  for 
instance, the productivity of coffee in the Bolovens, or seasonal paddy in the MLOC zones. 
Climate is not a determinant in degree of environmental impact on the present project. Rainfall 
varies considerably throughout the country and is heaviest (more than 2,600 millimeters) in the 
upland areas of the Bolovens in the south and the highlands of Borikhamxai and Khammouan. 
Lowland areas in Savannakhet and Khammouan are the driest, experiencing rainfall around 
1,400 mm annually.   
 
9.  Ecological resources and species diversity are generally high in all parts of the country, 
especially where natural environments prevail and human development is still at a low level.  
Forest cover is about 42% nationwide (1999), with the highest level of forest cover in the 
southern part of the country, inclusive of Savannakhet (about 59% of total land area). Forest 
cover is somewhat sparse in the three districts in Vientiane Province, and land use shows a 
mixture of forested areas (mixed deciduous and dry dipterocarp), bamboo and ray forested 
areas, scrub, and wet rice cultivation on land under agricultural use.    
10.  The project areas in Savannakhet Province contain some degraded dry dipterocarp 
forest, with about 15% in scrub. Lowland areas near the Mekong are dominated by wet rice 
cultivation. Paddy dominates throughout the areas where roadways are being constructed. 
Project areas in Khammouan Province are low in elevation and dominated by paddy production 
and dry dipterocarp forest. The project area in Champassak along the river has a predominance 
of land in agricultural use under wet rice cultivation, with dry dipterocarp forest and some scrub 
and grassland. The cropped area in the districts on the right (west) bank of the river is upwards 
of 28% of the total land area. 
11.  National biodiversity conservation areas (NBCAs) make up about 14% of the total land 
area of the country in 20 separate NBCAs, with another 276 conservation or protection forests 
(International Conservation Union [IUCN], 1999). Wetlands are numerous in the vicinity of the 
Project. Lowland environments throughout the Lao PDR are subject to flooding during the wet 
season because of their flat slopes, and contain a variety of plant and animal species.

D.  Potential Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures  
1.  Farming Support 
 
13.  The Project will introduce new intensification technologies to smallholders to intensify the 
production  of  wet  season  rice,  nonrice  cash  crops  during  the  dry  season,  livestock,  and 
fisheries. The method used will be participatory selection and adoption of techniques that 
enable  farmers  to  make  sound  resource  management  decisions,  taking  into  account  the 
continuously changing environment of an open market economy. This approach is a farmer 
demand-driven participatory process, which will form the basis of the national extension system 
of the National Agricultural and Forestry Extension Service (NAFES), now under development. 
14.  Fertilizer use in the Lao PDR has been historically low, but there is evidence it is 
increasing.  The  application  of  appropriate  technology  through  the  agriculture  extension 
agencies can mitigate against excessive fertilizer use. Given the history of low use rates and 
extension advice, Lao PDR farmers are not likely to excessively apply fertilizer. Streams are not 
susceptible to eutrophication except during the low flow season, when fertilizer loss could occur 
from irrigated fields supporting dry season rice crops. Farmer support by the extension agencies 
involves routine analyses of soil samples for soil pH, nitrate, phosphorous, and potassium. The 
extension agencies should provide training in production and use of organic fertilizer and soil 
natural conditioning agents to supplement chemical fertilizer use, such as compost from urban, 
periurban, and agricultural wastes.   
 
15.  Three types of livestock production is envisioned by provincial officials in the project 
areas,  with  increases  in  each  type  by  about  20%  over  the  next  5  years:  (i)  upland  or 
mountainous area grazing within production forests where some ground fodder propagates, 
involving cattle, buffaloes, and goats; (ii) lowland foraging among dry deciduous forest that has 
been  partially  converted  to  improved  pasture,  again  for  cattle,  buffaloes  and  goats;  and 
(iii) animal propagation near towns aiming at small livestock (pigs, chickens, ducks and goats). 
Livestock can have a wide range of effects on rangeland ecosystems that can be both positive 
and negative, and grazing impacts can be seen at the species, community, and landscape 
levels.  Therefore,  the  technology  transfer  component  of  the  proposed  Project  needs  to 
incorporate a program for monitoring effects of livestock on various ecosystem types within the 
project area with the aim of minimizing detrimental impacts while supporting good management 
practice.  
 
16.  After rice, livestock and fisheries are the most important ingredients of the Lao farm 
income. A knowledge base for rural aquaculture is needed to define the range of appropriate 
technologies and their social and economic profiles. This is the approach proposed in the 
Project. The proposed Project calls for a limited number of pilot projects within each regional 
network to be set up at the local administrative and agro-ecological/ecological levels. These 
pilot studies should be viewed as public policy experiments. The development of aquaculture

  3.  Rural Infrastructure Development 
 
19.  The Project will provide for the rehabilitation of 89.5 kilometers (km) and construction of 
70 km of strategic roads, identified as the highest priority rural access roads in the project area. 
These  roads  are  (i)  the  Pakse-Champassak-Soukhouma-Mounlapamok  road  (Road  14-A), 
which links the impoverished but potentially productive lower Mekong plain of Champassak 
Province to the highly commercial east-west corridor of Paksong-Pakse and the Thai border; (ii) 
the Champhone-Xonbuli road in Savannakhet Province, which links the potentially productive 
Xonbuli District to the commercially active east-west corridor in Savannakhet, which connects to 
the border region with Thailand; and (iii) the Songkhone-Thapasoun road, which links the 
commercial center of Songkhone District in Savannakhet Province to a key Mekong River 
border trading market with Thailand. 
 
20.  In Savannakhet, the roadway from Songkhone to Thapasoun (Section B) does not pass 
through wetlands. The area is dominated by paddy likely to be subject to seasonal flooding. 
Section A from Muang Champhone to Muang Xonbuli crosses a wetlands area, which causes 
the roadway to be impassable during the wet season. The Xe Champhone wetlands, an area of 
some 240 square kilometers, is oriented north - south and covers a distance of some 35 km. 
Roadway width will need to be widened about 3–4 m in order to obtain side slopes allowing the 
roadway to be raised some 1–2 m. Therefore, the impact of the Project on the wetlands will be 
insignificant.  
21.  In Champassak Province, Roadway Section C from Champassak to Soukhouma will be 
rehabilitated. This passes through the area identified as the Soukhouma Wetlands Group; 
however, the land near the roadway is currently in paddy production, and there are no wetland

A.  Justification 
 
1.  The private sector in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) is very small and 
in a nascent stage of development. In addition, the Lao PDR is viewed as a very risky place to 
invest. The majority of the limited number of investors in the country invest in projects with 
short-term  capital  recovery  (such  as  hotels,  timber  extraction  and  wood  processing,  and 
textiles). The expected capital recovery in most cases does not exceed 18-24 months. Under 
normal conditions, agribusinesses require a minimum of 5 years for investment recovery.  
 
2.  The  critical  component  of  agricultural  demand-side  strengthening  is  agribusiness 
development. Achieving this objective depends on mobilizing agribusiness investments in the 
project area. Strengthening marketing chains between farmers and domestic agribusinesses 
depends on strengthening the skills and capacity of agroenterprises and promoting the entry of 
new value-adding agribusinesses into the sector. The agribusiness sector in the Lao PDR is 
presently very thin and burdened by major constraints.  
 
3.  The present operations of agribusinesses are constrained by a variety of factors: (i) 
acute shortage of both investment capital and working capital; (ii) acute shortage of technical 
skills; (iii) insufficient raw material supply; (iv) heavy dependence on imported processing raw 
materials and managerial expertise; (v) lack of production, trade, management, and marketing 
experience;  (vi)  very  limited  understanding  of  existing  markets;  (vii)  low  local  demand  for 
diversified food commodities; (viii) absence of local processing facilities capable of absorbing 
large  quantities  of  produce;  (ix)  low  levels    of  production  and  management  technology; 
(x) limited  number  of  agricultural  commodity  traders;  (xi)  very  weak  commercial  networks 
throughout  the  country;  (xii)  risk  imposed  by  the  uncertain  legal  environment;  and 
(xiii) difficulties with contract enforcement. 
 
4.  There are only 582 registered businesses in Lao PDR. Thirty percent of these are micro 
scale agroprocessing cottage industries at the household and village levels employing 2 or 3 
persons.  In  addition  to  micro  cottage  industries,  there  are  15  small-  to  medium-scale 
agribusinesses employing 50-300 persons. Eighty percent of these are located in Vientiane 
Municipality, just beyond the project area.

FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC ANALYSES 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The project components promote diversification and commercialization of agricultural 
products that the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) has an underlying comparative 
advantage, so that smallholder farmers can increase food security and cash income. The 
economic analysis was undertaken on the Project as a whole covering all four components 
because the crop production benefits are to arise from these Project investments as a mutually 
supporting and integrated package. Associated and linked investments in roads, provision of 
production supports, and wider support for agribusinesses are all essential for smallholders to 
increase production and earn cash income through improved access to factors/inputs as well as 
functioning output markets. The financial analysis, on the other hand, focused only on the 
viability of representative farm models under the Project. Crop budgets and farm models were 
developed to determine incremental farm incomes. 
 
B.  Assumptions Used for Farm Models 
 
2.  The Project is expected to increase productivity through better farming practices, and to 
facilitate farmers’ commercial production and diversification. The calculation of financial and 
economic benefits was based on per hectare crop budgets for wet season rice, dry season rice, 
corn, peanut, soybean, cabbage, and garlic. The farm models assume that households apply 
the extended technology only on a proportion of their planted area first, but that this proportion 
rises to a natural plateau of three quarters of targeted households’ wet season planted area and 
to 60% of the total area for dry season cultivation by Year 7. 
 
3.  Wet Season Production. Average wet season rice yields should increase from 1.5 tons 
per hectare (ha) to 2.3 tons/ha, and wet season rice output is assumed to be 5% better in 
quality (mainly due to earlier harvesting) on average under the with-Project situation. The 
Project will cover 54 villages in each of 16 districts (a total of 864 villages), and the extension 
component is expected to impact some 20% of the total households within a district with wet 
season  cultivation  technology  changes.  Assuming  that  roughly  half  of  villagers  actively 
participate in the extension component, about 40% of participating households in those targeted 
villages should be adopting the wet season technology by Year 7 (Table A13.1).  
 
4.  Dry  Season  Production.  Overall  average  dry  season  (irrigated)  rice  yields  should 
increase from 3 tons/ha to 3.2 tons/ha with the Project. There will be a cropping shift towards 
combinations  of  nonrice  crops  in  the  dry  season,  which  will  become  broadly  increasingly 
valuable (i.e., in moving from diversification mix 1 through diversification mix 2 to diversification 
mix 3) over time.1 The extension component expects to impact 60–75% of the households in 
each  district  that  undertake  dry  season  cultivation. As  only  between  12%  and  16%  of  all 
households in the project provinces undertake dry season cultivation, this is equivalent to an 
impact on about 10% of all households in the project area. This target is technically realistic, as 
all the villages with current access to dry season cultivation will be selected to participate in the 
project extension efforts. The estimate of impacted dry season areas assumes new irrigation 
scheme development with an annual average growth rate of 5% over the Year 1–7 period.

C.  Financial Analysis 
 
5.  Financial Viability of Representative Farms. A financial analysis was undertaken to 
estimate the effects of project investments on the income of beneficiary farmers by comparing 
with-  and  without-Project  scenarios.  In  line  with  the  prevailing  size  of  irrigated  land  per 
household, crop budgets and farm models were prepared to determine incremental farm income 
as a result of the project investments. The incremental revenues were valued using financial 
farm gate prices. The costs included full operation and maintenance (O&M) costs, water fees, 
and the cost of rehabilitation of drainage and irrigation. The results of the financial analysis 
indicate that each representative farm is financially viable (Table A13.2). Farm-level returns to 
project investments are highly positive; each farm model in the four provinces is expected to 
generate a return of around 50-70% increase over the without-Project situation. As the farm 
income analysis assumes the costs of O&M of irrigation schemes, postharvest activities, and 
transportation to be covered by farmers, the analysis shows that the beneficiary farmers should 
be able to afford such levies and the proposed farm models will be financially sustainable. 
 
6.  Government Budgetary Implication. The Project will have relatively minor budgetary 
implications  consisting  of  (i)  incremental  operating  costs  of  the  extension  system,  and  (ii) 
incremental maintenance costs of the project roads. The aggregate incremental costs of the 
proposed extension system account for less than 0.01% of the Government’s annual budget 
(operating  and  capital  costs)  for  the  agriculture  sector,  and  less  than  0.2%  of  the  annual 
allocation for 1999–2001. Incremental operating costs for extension services in the project 
provinces  during  project  implementation  will  be  financed  by  the  loan  funds.  As  for  the 
maintenance cost of the project roads, which is estimated to be about $60,000 per year, 
maintenance of national road sections will be financed out of the Road Maintenance Fund, 
which  provides  5–to-1  matching  fund  for  any  locally  generated  revenues.  While  provincial 
governments are responsible for maintenance of rural access roads, the provinces and/or the 
Department of Roads in the Ministry of Communication, Transport, Post, and Construction has 
also assured the provision of adequate funding for routine maintenance of all project roads.  
 
D.  Economic Analysis 
 
7.  The economic viability of the Project was analyzed comparing the estimated benefits 
under the without-Project and with-Project situations for the 20-year life of the Project. In the 
case of the without-Project situation, there is no expected deterioration or decline of yields and 
areas planted/harvested in the absence of the proposed Project investment, and therefore 
without-Project and current situations are de facto the same thing. The economic analysis is 
presented in 2002 constant terms, and economic costs and benefits are estimated using the 
domestic numeraire.  
 
8.  Investment and recurrent costs were segregated into tradable, nontraded, and labor 
components, and converted into economic price using financial process net of taxes, duties, and 
subsidies. A shadow exchange rate factor of 1.1 is used to value tradable resources converted 
at the prevailing/official exchange rate of KN9,470 (July 2002) to the US dollar for the economic 
analysis.  As regards specific conversion factors, a shadow wage rate factor of 0.9 is used for 
rural labor in the farm budgets, reflecting average prevailing levels of rural unemployment and 
underemployment throughout the Lao PDR. 
 
9.  The Project’s estimated direct benefits comprise (i) crop production benefits that stem 
from  yield  increments  and  price  impacts  covering  an  area  of  about  30,000  ha  (9,000  ha 
irrigated), and (ii) reduced vehicle operating costs (VOC) for non-agricultural traffic on the

project roads.  The calculation of VOC saving assumed that one third of traffic is entirely non-
agricultural in nature, based on historical trends, and no benefits were estimated for time 
savings. Benefits generated by the livestock and fisheries extension activities were not included 
in the analysis, because no directly identifiable benefits are apparent from the project outputs. 
 
10.  The base case economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the Project is estimated to be 
19.9% (net present value = KN80,100 million, discounted at 12%). This quite positive estimate 
essentially arises from the scale of the latent economic opportunity, indicating that the Project 
will help transform an underlying comparative advantage into realized competitive performance. 
Just over half the cropping benefits arise from wet season rice cultivation and the remainder 
from dry season interventions. About one fifth of total project economic benefits come from VOC 
savings. 
 
11.   The project beneficiaries comprise farmers, farm workers, and their families whose 
livelihood  depend  on  about  106,700  ha  of  land,  and  agroprocessors,  and  commercial 
agricultural traders. The total number of direct wet season beneficiary households is about 
33,000  and  dry  season  direct  beneficiary  households  are  some  16,000.  Many  of  these 
beneficiaries are poor farm workers and small subsistence farmers, who would benefit from 
increased  income  through  improved  production  of  wet  season  rice.  In  addition  to  these, 
additional individuals and households will benefit from the road improvements (including labor 
employed  to  build  roads—up  to  500  full-time  jobs  created),  livestock  and  fisheries 
demonstrations, and the various agribusiness support interventions. Total project beneficiaries 
will likely be at least 45,000 households. The distribution analysis of project benefits suggested 
that smallholders are the primary beneficiaries of the Project, followed by road users. The 
Project is also expected to have a modest but positive impact on poverty-reduction in the long 
term: The poverty impact ratio of the Project is estimated to be 25%, which compares with the 
national poverty incidence of 39.2%. 
 
E.  Sensitivity Analysis 
 
12.  A sensitivity analysis was carried out to test the impact of higher project costs, lower 
project benefits, lower production improvements, and a delay in project implementation. The 
Project’s returns are relatively robust; increasing the costs by 20% causing the base case EIRR 
to fall to 17%, and cropping benefits have to fall 42% for the EIRR to fall below 12% (Table 
A14.3). Switching values for major variables indicate that overall costs have to rise by 72% for 
the Project to become nonviable. Rice yields/prices and adoption rates would have to fall by half 
for the same outcome. The omission of VOC benefits entirely does not affect Project viability. 
Quantitative risk-based analyses suggest that the probability of the Project achieving less than 
acceptable economic is very low at about 6%. 
 
F.  Component Viability Analysis 
 
13.  Although the Project design logic is based on the fact that several linked interventions 
are required for both on-farm and off-farm activities to deliver the expected benefits, it can also 
be useful to look at the economic viability of the major components separately. For the extension 
component, if all its directly attributable costs are compared with the cropping benefits from the 
Project, the “component” EIRR is 37%. For the rural infrastructure component the estimated 
economic return is 34%.
